elements.content: Many zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are promising candidates for use in separation technologies. Comprising large cavities interconnected by small windows they can be used, at least in principle, as molecular sieves where molecules smaller than the window size are able to diffuse into the material while larger molecules are rejected. However, “swing effect” or “gate opening” phenomena resulting in an enlargement of the windows have proven to be detrimental. Here, we present the first systematic experimental and computational study of the effect of chemical functionalization of the imidazole linker on the framework dynamics. Using high-pressure (HP) single-crystal X-ray diffraction, density functional theory, and grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations, we show that in the isostructural ZIF-8, ZIF-90, and ZIF-65 functional groups of increasing polarity (−CH3, −CHO, and −NO2) on the imidazole linkers provide control over the degree of rotation and thus the critical window diameter. On application of pressure, the substituted imidazolate rings rotate, resulting in an increase in both pore volume and content. Our results show that the interplay between the guest molecules and the chemical function of the imidazole linker is essential for directing the swing effect in ZIF frameworks and therefore the adsorption performance.
elements.clean_text: Many zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are promising candidates for use in separation technologies. Comprising large cavities interconnected by small windows they can be used, at least in principle, as molecular sieves where molecules smaller than the window size are able to diffuse into the material while larger molecules are rejected. However, "swing effect" or "gate opening" phenomena resulting in an enlargement of the windows have proven to be detrimental. Here, we present the first systematic experimental and computational study of the effect of chemical functionalization of the imidazole linker on the framework dynamics. Using high-pressure (HP) single-crystal X-ray diffraction, density functional theory, and grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations, we show that in the isostructural ZIF-8, ZIF-90, and ZIF-65 functional groups of increasing polarity (-CH3, -CHO, and -NO2) on the imidazole linkers provide control over the degree of rotation and thus the critical window diameter. On application of pressure, the substituted imidazolate rings rotate, resulting in an increase in both pore volume and content. Our results show that the interplay between the guest molecules and the chemical function of the imidazole linker is essential for directing the swing effect in ZIF frameworks and therefore the adsorption performance.

elements.content: Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are a class of chemically stable and commercial porous materials. Their structures are based on zeolite topologies, where imidazolate (Im, C3H3N2 –) and Zn2+, Co2+, Li+, or B3+ ions replace the oxygen and Al3+/Si4+ species found in zeolites. Incorporating the Im linker increases the pore sizes compared to zeolites. The ZIF family contains over 100 frameworks which adopt zeolite topologies such as rho (ZIF-11), dft (ZIF-3), and cag (ZIF-4). These different topologies are made possible through functionalization of the imidazole linker, which results in a change in pore size and surface chemistry. This has led to a plethora of applications of ZIFs in catalysis, drug delivery, and gas storage. To fully exploit the potential of ZIFs, it is necessary to fully understand the structural changes of the framework upon guest uptake and the resulting mechanical properties. There has been little work on the mechanical response; for example, ZIF-4 (Zn­(Im)2, Im = imidazolate) is known to desolvate to a dense form and ZIF-11 (Zn­(bIm)2, bIm = benzimidazolate) has been studied to understand how solvent plays a role in stabilizing the structure against mechnical stress in ball milling.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are a class of chemically stable and commercial porous materials. Their structures are based on zeolite topologies, where imidazolate (Im, C3H3N2 -) and Zn2+, Co2+, Li+, or B3+ ions replace the oxygen and Al3+/Si4+ species found in zeolites. Incorporating the Im linker increases the pore sizes compared to zeolites. The ZIF family contains over 100 frameworks which adopt zeolite topologies such as rho (ZIF-11), dft (ZIF-3), and cag (ZIF-4). These different topologies are made possible through functionalization of the imidazole linker, which results in a change in pore size and surface chemistry. This has led to a plethora of applications of ZIFs in catalysis, drug delivery, and gas storage. To fully exploit the potential of ZIFs, it is necessary to fully understand the structural changes of the framework upon guest uptake and the resulting mechanical properties. There has been little work on the mechanical response; for example, ZIF-4 (Zn(Im)2, Im = imidazolate) is known to desolvate to a dense form and ZIF-11 (Zn(bIm)2, bIm = benzimidazolate) has been studied to understand how solvent plays a role in stabilizing the structure against mechnical stress in ball milling.

elements.content: One of the ZIFs that has been widely studied is ZIF-8, (Zn­(mIm)2, mIm = 2-methylimidazolate), which crystallizes in the cubic space group I4̅3m (a = 16.9856(16) Å, V = 4900.5(8) Å3) and adopts the sodalite topology (a). At ambient pressure and temperature, ZIF-8 contains one central nanosized pore per unit cell, with a volume of ∼2500 Å3 and pore diameter of 11.6 Å. Connecting these large nanopores are eight six-membered ring (6MR) windows ca. 3.0 Å in diameter and six smaller four-membered ring (4MR) windows of ca. 0.8 Å (a, ). Multiple studies have made use of these critically narrow 6MR windows for gas separation in, for example, membranes. However, H2/CH4 separation experiments (with kinetic diameters of 2.85 and 3.80 Å, respectively) illustrated that many molecules with kinetic diameters larger than the 6MR window, for example, O2, N2, and CH4, permeate through the structure.
elements.clean_text: One of the ZIFs that has been widely studied is ZIF-8, (Zn(mIm)2, mIm = 2-methylimidazolate), which crystallizes in the cubic space group I4̅3m (a = 16.9856(16) Å, V = 4900.5(8) Å3) and adopts the sodalite topology (a). At ambient pressure and temperature, ZIF-8 contains one central nanosized pore per unit cell, with a volume of ~2500 Å3 and pore diameter of 11.6 Å. Connecting these large nanopores are eight six-membered ring (6MR) windows ca. 3.0 Å in diameter and six smaller four-membered ring (4MR) windows of ca. 0.8 Å (a, ). Multiple studies have made use of these critically narrow 6MR windows for gas separation in, for example, membranes. However, H2/CH4 separation experiments (with kinetic diameters of 2.85 and 3.80 Å, respectively) illustrated that many molecules with kinetic diameters larger than the 6MR window, for example, O2, N2, and CH4, permeate through the structure.

elements.content: (a) Unit cell of ZIF-8. (b) The angle, θ, represented as the angle that the 100 hkl plane makes with the imidazole linker of the four-membered window. (c) Unit cell of ZIF-90 and (d) unit cell of ZIF-65. Zn tetrahedra, cyan; C, black; N, blue; O, red. Note the more closed 4MR of ZIF-65 compared to those of ZIF-8 and ZIF-90. H atoms in all structures and the disorder of the CHO functional group in ZIF-90 have been removed for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Unit cell of ZIF-8. (b) The angle, θ, represented as the angle that the 100 hkl plane makes with the imidazole linker of the four-membered window. (c) Unit cell of ZIF-90 and (d) unit cell of ZIF-65. Zn tetrahedra, cyan; C, black; N, blue; O, red. Note the more closed 4MR of ZIF-65 compared to those of ZIF-8 and ZIF-90. H atoms in all structures and the disorder of the CHO functional group in ZIF-90 have been removed for clarity.

elements.content:
Diameter of 4MR and 6MR Windows in ZIF-8, ZIF-65, and ZIF-90<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref> ZIF lattice parameter (Å) pore volume (Å3) Θ (deg) 4MR diameter (Å) 6MR diameter (Å) ZIF-8 16.9856(16) 2500 64.3 0.8 3.0 ZIF-90 17.0758(13) 2354 66.5 1.4 3.2 ZIF-65 17.3185(2) 2619 46.3 0.8 3.2

All diameters calculated in Mercury, with 0.2 Å grid spacing.

A structural explanation was later provided by Moggach et al., who reported a pressure-induced phase transition in diamond anvil cell experiments using a 4:1 methanol:ethanol hydrostatic medium. Initial cell volume expansion (for pressures up to 0.18 GPa) from penetration of the hydrostatic medium into the pores was followed by compression at 0.90 GPa. At 1.47 GPa, a single-crystal to single-crystal phase transition took place to a previously unobserved phase (referred to as ZIF-8-HP), involving rotation of the mIm linker. The angle of rotation, θ, defined as the angle between the (100) plane and the mean plane passing through the mIm ring increased from 64.3° at ambient pressure to 89.7° at 1.47 GPa( b). This rotation resulted in an increase in the diameter of the 4MR and 6MR windows from 0.8 to 2.2 Å and from 3.0 to 3.6 Å, allowing more MeOH and EtOH molecules to enter the framework.
elements.clean_text: A structural explanation was later provided by Moggach et al., who reported a pressure-induced phase transition in diamond anvil cell experiments using a 4:1 methanol:ethanol hydrostatic medium. Initial cell volume expansion (for pressures up to 0.18 GPa) from penetration of the hydrostatic medium into the pores was followed by compression at 0.90 GPa. At 1.47 GPa, a single-crystal to single-crystal phase transition took place to a previously unobserved phase (referred to as ZIF-8-HP), involving rotation of the mIm linker. The angle of rotation, θ, defined as the angle between the (100) plane and the mean plane passing through the mIm ring increased from 64.3° at ambient pressure to 89.7° at 1.47 GPa( b). This rotation resulted in an increase in the diameter of the 4MR and 6MR windows from 0.8 to 2.2 Å and from 3.0 to 3.6 Å, allowing more MeOH and EtOH molecules to enter the framework.

elements.content: Using a combination of grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations and in situ powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), Fairen-Jimenez et al. later demonstrated that the same phase transition took place upon gas adsorption at much lower pressure (for N2 at 77 K it can be observed at ∼0.02 bar) because of the adsorption of additional molecules in the 4MR windows. Zhang et al. showed that this phenomenon is dependent on the ZIF-8 particle size. In addition, the vibrational mode linked to the gate opening has been observed in the terahertz region (<50 cm–1) and predicted by ab initio density functional simulations. The effect of hydrostatic media on the compression of ZIF-8 has also been studied, demonstrating that the framework has different compressibilites in different media.
elements.clean_text: Using a combination of grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations and in situ powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), Fairen-Jimenez et al. later demonstrated that the same phase transition took place upon gas adsorption at much lower pressure (for N2 at 77 K it can be observed at ~0.02 bar) because of the adsorption of additional molecules in the 4MR windows. Zhang et al. showed that this phenomenon is dependent on the ZIF-8 particle size. In addition, the vibrational mode linked to the gate opening has been observed in the terahertz region (<50 cm-1) and predicted by ab initio density functional simulations. The effect of hydrostatic media on the compression of ZIF-8 has also been studied, demonstrating that the framework has different compressibilites in different media.

elements.content: Replacement of the −CH3 substituent on the mIm linker with either −CHO or −NO2 groups leads to the isostructural and isosymmetric ZIF-90 (Zn­(ICA))2, ICA = imidazolate-2-carboxyaldehyde) and ZIF-65 (Zn­(nIm)2, nIm = 2-nitroimidazolate), respectively (c,d). The chemical functionalization results in different linker orientations and therefore different values for θ and the 4MR and 6MR diameters (). These functionalities give the opportunity to tune the host–guest interactions which have been, for example, demonstrated for CO2 adsorption where postsynthetic modification of ZIF-90 enhanced H2 selectivity over CO2 and ZIF-65 displays an increased affinity for CO2, compared to ZIF-8 due to the NO2 functionality.
elements.clean_text: Replacement of the -CH3 substituent on the mIm linker with either -CHO or -NO2 groups leads to the isostructural and isosymmetric ZIF-90 (Zn(ICA))2, ICA = imidazolate-2-carboxyaldehyde) and ZIF-65 (Zn(nIm)2, nIm = 2-nitroimidazolate), respectively (c,d). The chemical functionalization results in different linker orientations and therefore different values for θ and the 4MR and 6MR diameters (). These functionalities give the opportunity to tune the host-guest interactions which have been, for example, demonstrated for CO2 adsorption where postsynthetic modification of ZIF-90 enhanced H2 selectivity over CO2  and ZIF-65 displays an increased affinity for CO2, compared to ZIF-8 due to the NO2 functionality.

elements.content: However, the influence of the functionality on the framework dynamics and mechanical properties has not been systematically studied. Here, we present a combined high-pressure (HP) single-crystal diffraction and computational study on three isostructural ZIFs: ZIF-8, ZIF-90, and ZIF-65 to understand the effect of imidazole functionality and guest molecule uptake on swing effect behavior.
elements.clean_text: However, the influence of the functionality on the framework dynamics and mechanical properties has not been systematically studied. Here, we present a combined high-pressure (HP) single-crystal diffraction and computational study on three isostructural ZIFs: ZIF-8, ZIF-90, and ZIF-65 to understand the effect of imidazole functionality and guest molecule uptake on swing effect behavior.

elements.content: Following X-ray data collection at ambient temperature and pressure, single crystals of both ZIF-90 and ZIF-65 were placed in modified Merrill-basset diamond anvil cells (DACs), along with ruby chips (for pressure calibration) and surrounded by methanol:ethanol (4:1) mixture (SI-1 for experimental details).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Following X-ray data collection at ambient temperature and pressure, single crystals of both ZIF-90 and ZIF-65 were placed in modified Merrill-basset diamond anvil cells (DACs), along with ruby chips (for pressure calibration) and surrounded by methanol:ethanol (4:1) mixture (SI-1 for experimental details).

elements.content: For ZIF-90, when pressue is increased to 0.34 GPa, the unit cell volume increased by 3.40%, resulting in an increase in pore size of 300 Å3 (). A small decrease in θ of 9.3° coincided with a decrease in electron density in the pores from 981 to 238 e–/uc (Figure S2 ). Upon increasing pressure further to 0.88 GPa, the unit cell compressed by 0.37% and θ increased from 21.3° to 78.6°. At this stage, transformation to a HP phase similar to that of ZIF-8-HP (hereafter referred to as ZIF-90-HP), was observed. θ continued increasing to 84.1° at 1.95 GPa, where the pore volume and content reached a maximum, measuring 2612 Å3 and 1087 e–/uc, respectively (Figure S2). The behavioral trends in θ and pore volume are similar to that for ZIF-8 reported previously, where a jump in θ from 59.7° to 89.7° between 0.96 and 1.47 GPa corresponds to the gate-opening transition to ZIF-8-HP. The maximum value of θ for ZIF-90-HP at 1.96 GPa was therefore slightly less than that of ZIF-8-HP at 1.47 GPa, though the larger 4MR window () of ZIF-90-HP explains the increase in pore volume and content compared to ZIF-8-HP (∼300 Å3 and 1087 e–/uc compared to 100 Å3 and ∼636 e–/uc).

A small decrease in θ of 9.3° coincided with a decrease in electron density in the pores from 981 to 238 e-/uc (Figure S2 ). Upon increasing pressure further to 0.88 GPa, the unit cell compressed by 0.37% and θ increased from 21.3° to 78.6°. At this stage, transformation to a HP phase similar to that of ZIF-8-HP (hereafter referred to as ZIF-90-HP), was observed. θ continued increasing to 84.1° at 1.95 GPa, where the pore volume and content reached a maximum, measuring 2612 Å3 and 1087 e-/uc, respectively (Figure S2). The behavioral trends in θ and pore volume are similar to that for ZIF-8 reported previously, where a jump in θ from 59.7° to 89.7° between 0.96 and 1.47 GPa corresponds to the gate-opening transition to ZIF-8-HP. The maximum value of θ for ZIF-90-HP at 1.96 GPa was therefore slightly less than that of ZIF-8-HP at 1.47 GPa, though the larger 4MR window () of ZIF-90-HP explains the increase in pore volume and content compared to ZIF-8-HP (~300 Å3 and 1087 e-/uc compared to 100 Å3 and ~636 e-/uc).

elements.content: Evolution of cell volumes (a) and θ (b) with pressure for ZIF-8 (green), ZIF-90 (red), and ZIF-65 (blue) in MeOH:EtOH (4:1), where AP and HP phases are represented by circles and squares, respectively. ZIF-8 data from original study by Moggach et al.

Asterisk marks the onset to the high-pressure phase.

Turning to ZIF-65, a unit cell volume expansion of 0.70%, and increase in pore void volume of ∼50 Å3 at 0.11 GPa, indicated hydrostatic media penetration into the pores. In contrast to the decrease in θ observed in ZIF-8 and ZIF-90, here θ increased from 46.3° to 48.5°. This rotation caused the 4MR window to increase in size from 0.8 to 1.0 Å, while the 6MR window remained unchanged (). Increasing pressure further to 0.73 GPa saw the onset of the ZIF-65-HP phase, which elicited a decrease in both unit cell volume (2%) and θ (from 48.6° to 37.3°). This corresponded to a decrease in 4MR diameter from 1.0 to 0.6 Å and an increase in the 6MR diameter from 3.2 to 3.6 Å.
elements.clean_text: Turning to ZIF-65, a unit cell volume expansion of 0.70%, and increase in pore void volume of ~50 Å3 at 0.11 GPa, indicated hydrostatic media penetration into the pores. In contrast to the decrease in θ observed in ZIF-8 and ZIF-90, here θ increased from 46.3° to 48.5°. This rotation caused the 4MR window to increase in size from 0.8 to 1.0 Å, while the 6MR window remained unchanged (). Increasing pressure further to 0.73 GPa saw the onset of the ZIF-65-HP phase, which elicited a decrease in both unit cell volume (2%) and θ (from 48.6° to 37.3°). This corresponded to a decrease in 4MR diameter from 1.0 to 0.6 Å and an increase in the 6MR diameter from 3.2 to 3.6 Å.

elements.content: Further increases in pressure to 4.77 GPa resulted in negligible changes to θ (30.9°) and a linear decrease in void volume. Compression of the unit cell volume was accompanied by a steady increase in electron density in the pore to 3.10 GPa (from 280 to ∼540 e–/uc), whereby a plateau was reached and maintained to 4.77 GPa. This latter pressure marked the highest pressure point for which diffraction data could be collected and solved (). Above this pressure, the single crystal fractured and became amorphous. ZIFs are often observed to become amorphous on direct compression, and have been predicted to be rather unstable on applying pressure. The inclusion of solvent stabilizes ZIF-65 to external pressure, which has also been seen in other MOFs such as CuBTC and MOF-5.
elements.clean_text: Further increases in pressure to 4.77 GPa resulted in negligible changes to θ (30.9°) and a linear decrease in void volume. Compression of the unit cell volume was accompanied by a steady increase in electron density in the pore to 3.10 GPa (from 280 to ~540 e-/uc), whereby a plateau was reached and maintained to 4.77 GPa. This latter pressure marked the highest pressure point for which diffraction data could be collected and solved (). Above this pressure, the single crystal fractured and became amorphous. ZIFs are often observed to become amorphous on direct compression, and have been predicted to be rather unstable on applying pressure. The inclusion of solvent stabilizes ZIF-65 to external pressure, which has also been seen in other MOFs such as CuBTC and MOF-5.

elements.content: Capped stick diagrams for (a) ZIF-8, (b) ZIF-90, and (c) ZIF-65 at ambient pressure and (d) ZIF-8, (e) ZIF-90, and (f) ZIF-65 in their respective HP forms at 1.47, 1.95, and 4.77 GPa, respectively. Purple shading represents the solvent accessible volume calculated with a probe size diameter of 3.4 Å (kinetic diameter of methanol) using Mercury. Note the increase in size of the channels linking the central nanopore through the 6MR windows on undergoing the transition.
elements.clean_text: 3  Capped stick diagrams for (a) ZIF-8, (b) ZIF-90, and (c) ZIF-65 at ambient pressure and (d) ZIF-8, (e) ZIF-90, and (f) ZIF-65 in their respective HP forms at 1.47, 1.95, and 4.77 GPa, respectively. Purple shading represents the solvent accessible volume calculated with a probe size diameter of 3.4 Å (kinetic diameter of methanol) using Mercury. Note the increase in size of the channels linking the central nanopore through the 6MR windows on undergoing the transition.

elements.content: The structure of ZIF-65-HP does not resemble that of ZIF-8-HP or ZIF-90-HP (). Rotation of the organic linkers to smaller values of θ was observed, compared to the latter two high-pressure structures which coincided with an increase in θ. Interestingly, the intermolecular N···O distance (where N is contained within one NO2 head group and O within an adjacent NO2 head group (Figure S3)) across the 4MR decreased by ∼0.5 Å (Table S3). The fact that these −NO2 groups move toward each other suggest that unlike CH3···CH3 interactions the interaction between these groups are mildly favorable. This rationale is consistent with the observation that, in certain geometries, stacking of NO2 groups leads to interaction energies comparable to CO···H–C interactions. As a result of these high-pressure geometries, adsorption of guest molecules is improved because of the increased size of channels linking the central nanopore (), encouraging percolation of guest molecules between pores.
elements.clean_text: The structure of ZIF-65-HP does not resemble that of ZIF-8-HP or ZIF-90-HP (). Rotation of the organic linkers to smaller values of θ was observed, compared to the latter two high-pressure structures which coincided with an increase in θ. Interestingly, the intermolecular N⋅⋅⋅O distance (where N is contained within one NO2 head group and O within an adjacent NO2 head group (Figure S3)) across the 4MR decreased by ~0.5 Å (Table S3). The fact that these -NO2 groups move toward each other suggest that unlike CH3⋅⋅⋅CH3 interactions the interaction between these groups are mildly favorable. This rationale is consistent with the observation that, in certain geometries, stacking of NO2 groups leads to interaction energies comparable to CO⋅⋅⋅H-C interactions. As a result of these high-pressure geometries, adsorption of guest molecules is improved because of the increased size of channels linking the central nanopore (), encouraging percolation of guest molecules between pores.

elements.content: By using a mixture of 4:1 methanol:ethanol, we used a pressure-transmitting medium that can enter the pores of the ZIFs and is hydrostatic to higher pressures (10.5 GPa) than pure methanol. To determine its role in the transformation of the AP to the HP structures, single-point energy calculations were undertaken on guest-free ZIF-8, ZIF-90, and ZIF-65 as a function of ligand rotation. To begin with, geometry optimization of the ambient pressure structures using the periodic CASTEP code (for full details see SI-1) were performed, giving values of θ comparable to the ambient pressure values, measuring 63.4°, 55.5°, and 50.2° for ZIF-8, ZIF-90, and ZIF-65, respectively, compared to the ambient crystal structure values of 64.3°, 66.5°, and 46.5°. Deviation in the latter two cases is ascribed to solvent presence in the pores in the experimental structures. θ was then varied (i.e., the Im linkers rotated) by 30°, in 5° increments, in both positive and negative directions relative to the equilibrium structure. Relative energies with respect to the equilibrium structure were calculated and are given in kJ mol–1 per imidazolate linker. shows the results of the single-point energy calculations (see Table S4 for more information). Relatively flat potential energy surfaces were revealed, indicating that energy penalties to rotate the linkers are very low. For ZIF-8 (which had a starting θ of 64.3°), the energy penalty to the rotation of the mIm linker to the ZIF-8-HP phase (where θ = 89.7°) was relatively small (∼8 kJ mol–1). However, the same rotation by 25° in the opposite direction had a much larger energy penalty, equating to ∼160 kJ mol–1. Due to steric hindrance of the methyl groups, the rotation of the linker clearly has a definite preference, and for the opposite rotation to occur, the energies of adsorption would have to be very large, much larger than what might be expected for adsorption of MeOH which is usually on the order of tens of kJ mol–1.

Deviation in the latter two cases is ascribed to solvent presence in the pores in the experimental structures. θ was then varied (i.e., the Im linkers rotated) by 30°, in 5° increments, in both positive and negative directions relative to the equilibrium structure. Relative energies with respect to the equilibrium structure were calculated and are given in kJ mol-1 per imidazolate linker.  shows the results of the single-point energy calculations (see Table S4 for more information). Relatively flat potential energy surfaces were revealed, indicating that energy penalties to rotate the linkers are very low. For ZIF-8 (which had a starting θ of 64.3°), the energy penalty to the rotation of the mIm linker to the ZIF-8-HP phase (where θ = 89.7°) was relatively small (~8 kJ mol-1). However, the same rotation by 25° in the opposite direction had a much larger energy penalty, equating to ~160 kJ mol-1. Due to steric hindrance of the methyl groups, the rotation of the linker clearly has a definite preference, and for the opposite rotation to occur, the energies of adsorption would have to be very large, much larger than what might be expected for adsorption of MeOH which is usually on the order of tens of kJ mol-1.

elements.content: Single-point energy calculations showing the energy landscape of the rotation of Im ligands for ZIF-8, ZIF-90, and ZIF-65. Dotted lines denote the crystallographic ambient-pressure phase angle of rotation and dashed lines denote the high-pressure angle of rotation.
elements.clean_text: 4  Single-point energy calculations showing the energy landscape of the rotation of Im ligands for ZIF-8, ZIF-90, and ZIF-65. Dotted lines denote the crystallographic ambient-pressure phase angle of rotation and dashed lines denote the high-pressure angle of rotation.

elements.content: For both ZIF-90 and ZIF-65, the potential energy landscape determined was relatively flat in comparison to ZIF-8, with only small energy penalties of a few kJ mol–1 regardless of the direction of rotation. The difference in behavior observed for negative linker rotations is attributed to unfavorable CH3/CH3 clashing (in the case of ZIF-8), compared to more favorable −CHO or -NO2 headgroup interactions in the case of ZIF-90 and ZIF-65, respectively. On compressing ZIF-90, the imidazole rings rotated by approximately +20°. This equated to an energy penalty of just 6.1 kJ mol–1. The corresponding backward rotation equated to 7.5 kJ mol–1. Similarly, for ZIF-65, while the highest degree of rotation was −20° at 4.77 GPa, which equated to 25.6 kJ mol–1, the corresponding forward rotation was more favorable at 5.6 kJ mol–1. For all three frameworks, positive rotations are favored in the absence of any guests. The negative rotations observed in the HP experiments for ZIF-65 therefore indicate a much greater guest–host interaction than for ZIF-90 and ZIF-8.
elements.clean_text: For both ZIF-90 and ZIF-65, the potential energy landscape determined was relatively flat in comparison to ZIF-8, with only small energy penalties of a few kJ mol-1 regardless of the direction of rotation. The difference in behavior observed for negative linker rotations is attributed to unfavorable CH3/CH3 clashing (in the case of ZIF-8), compared to more favorable -CHO or -NO2 headgroup interactions in the case of ZIF-90 and ZIF-65, respectively. On compressing ZIF-90, the imidazole rings rotated by approximately +20°. This equated to an energy penalty of just 6.1 kJ mol-1. The corresponding backward rotation equated to 7.5 kJ mol-1. Similarly, for ZIF-65, while the highest degree of rotation was -20° at 4.77 GPa, which equated to 25.6 kJ mol-1, the corresponding forward rotation was more favorable at 5.6 kJ mol-1. For all three frameworks, positive rotations are favored in the absence of any guests. The negative rotations observed in the HP experiments for ZIF-65 therefore indicate a much greater guest-host interaction than for ZIF-90 and ZIF-8.

elements.content: To locate the position of guest MeOH molecules, and to quantify guest–host interactions for ZIF-8, ZIF-65, and ZIF-90, grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) calculations were carried out (for full simulation details see SI-1). Both the ambient pressure (AP) and the highest HP crystallographic structures were used as models in separate GCMC simulations. In this way, the effect of changing the linker orientation on the uptake of methanol into the pores can be directly studied. During the simulations the energies and positions of the methanol molecules were stored, and from this, potential energy histograms constructed (). Compared to the AP structures, the guest–host interaction energies for all HP structures decreased, that is, became more favorable. The driving force for HP phases, for all systems studied, is therefore to maximize the interaction between the framework and the adsorbatesomething that was observed before for CH4 in ZIF-8.
elements.clean_text: To locate the position of guest MeOH molecules, and to quantify guest-host interactions for ZIF-8, ZIF-65, and ZIF-90, grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) calculations were carried out (for full simulation details see SI-1). Both the ambient pressure (AP) and the highest HP crystallographic structures were used as models in separate GCMC simulations. In this way, the effect of changing the linker orientation on the uptake of methanol into the pores can be directly studied. During the simulations the energies and positions of the methanol molecules were stored, and from this, potential energy histograms constructed (). Compared to the AP structures, the guest-host interaction energies for all HP structures decreased, that is, became more favorable. The driving force for HP phases, for all systems studied, is therefore to maximize the interaction between the framework and the adsorbatesomething that was observed before for CH4 in ZIF-8.

elements.content: Interaction energy histograms obtained from the highest loading of methanol in ZIFs from GCMC simulations. With ZIF-65, ZIF-90, and ZIF-8 in blue, red, and green, respectively. AP (dark) and HP (light) refer to the ambient- and high-pressure structures, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 5  Interaction energy histograms obtained from the highest loading of methanol in ZIFs from GCMC simulations. With ZIF-65, ZIF-90, and ZIF-8 in blue, red, and green, respectively. AP (dark) and HP (light) refer to the ambient- and high-pressure structures, respectively.

elements.content: To understand the effect that the guest–host interactions have on the direction of rotation, GCMC simulations were also undertaken on hypothetical structures of ZIF-90 and ZIF-65 where the linkers were rotated by the same degree but in the opposite direction to their HP experimental structures. For example, in ZIF-65-HP, the linkers rotate by −20° compared to the AP phase, so the linkers in the hypothetical structure (named ZIF-65-HYPO) were rotated by +20°. Likewise, the ICA linkers in ZIF-90-HP rotate by +25°, so the linkers in ZIF-90-HYPO were rotated by −25°. shows the resulting methanol–framework interaction energy mapped onto surfaces. The color of the surface signifies the strength of the interaction. In both ZIF-90-HYPO and ZIF-65-HYPO, the interaction energy between methanol and the framework increases (i.e., becomes less favorable) compared to the experimentally observed structuresa strong indication that the guest–framework energies dictate the direction of ligand rotation. See SI-4 for more information on the interaction energies.
elements.clean_text: To understand the effect that the guest-host interactions have on the direction of rotation, GCMC simulations were also undertaken on hypothetical structures of ZIF-90 and ZIF-65 where the linkers were rotated by the same degree but in the opposite direction to their HP experimental structures. For example, in ZIF-65-HP, the linkers rotate by -20° compared to the AP phase, so the linkers in the hypothetical structure (named ZIF-65-HYPO) were rotated by +20°. Likewise, the ICA linkers in ZIF-90-HP rotate by +25°, so the linkers in ZIF-90-HYPO were rotated by -25°.  shows the resulting methanol-framework interaction energy mapped onto surfaces. The color of the surface signifies the strength of the interaction. In both ZIF-90-HYPO and ZIF-65-HYPO, the interaction energy between methanol and the framework increases (i.e., becomes less favorable) compared to the experimentally observed structuresa strong indication that the guest-framework energies dictate the direction of ligand rotation. See SI-4 for more information on the interaction energies.

elements.content: Framework–methanol interaction energy surfaces for (a) ZIF-65-HP, (b) ZIF-65-HYPO, (b) ZIF-90-HP, and (d) ZIF-90-HYPO. The scale on the surface represents the interaction energy with blue = 10 kJ mol–1 and red = −40 kJ mol–1. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 6  Framework-methanol interaction energy surfaces for (a) ZIF-65-HP, (b) ZIF-65-HYPO, (b) ZIF-90-HP, and (d) ZIF-90-HYPO. The scale on the surface represents the interaction energy with blue = 10 kJ mol-1 and red = -40 kJ mol-1. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Analyzing the position of the methanol molecules in the pores sheds light on the differences of packing within the structures, and why each HP structure was preferred over their hypothetical counterpart. For ZIF-65-HP (a) the most favorable interaction for methanol with the framework (−40 to −30 kJ mol–1) was located just above the four-membered window, interacting strongly with the four overlapping NO2 groups. The second strongest sites (−30 to −20 kJ mol–1) are found percolating through the structure connecting adjacent pores through the 6MR. The third strongest site (−20 to −10 kJ mol–1) can be found in the pore, as well as in the 6MR window; however, these molecules have less favorable orientations to the second site. The final site (−10 to 0 kJ mol–1) was found in the center of the pore, accounting for the low interaction energy these methanol molecules experience with ZIF-65.
elements.clean_text: Analyzing the position of the methanol molecules in the pores sheds light on the differences of packing within the structures, and why each HP structure was preferred over their hypothetical counterpart. For ZIF-65-HP (a) the most favorable interaction for methanol with the framework (-40 to -30 kJ mol-1) was located just above the four-membered window, interacting strongly with the four overlapping NO2 groups. The second strongest sites (-30 to -20 kJ mol-1) are found percolating through the structure connecting adjacent pores through the 6MR. The third strongest site (-20 to -10 kJ mol-1) can be found in the pore, as well as in the 6MR window; however, these molecules have less favorable orientations to the second site. The final site (-10 to 0 kJ mol-1) was found in the center of the pore, accounting for the low interaction energy these methanol molecules experience with ZIF-65.

elements.content: For ZIF-65-HYPO (b), there were no methanol–framework interactions below −30 kJ mol–1, most likely due to the orientation of the framework which is now in a gate-opened structure. With the 4MR window open, this orientation does not allow good contact with methanol. The most favorable sites in ZIF-65-HYPO have energies on the order of −30 to −20 kJ mol–1. These sites, like in ZIF-65-HP, sit in the 6MR window, thereby connecting the pores throughout the crystal lattice, but with less favorable interaction energies (by ca. 5 kJ mol–1) than in ZIF-65-HP. The second site (−20 to −10 kJ mol–1) was also present in the 6MR window and in the central pore, but the mean interaction energy is again around ∼5 kJ mol–1 less than that of ZIF-65-HP. The weakest binding site in ZIF-65-HYPO (−10 to 0 kJ mol–1) occupied the center of the pore, and the density was much higher than that in ZIF-65-HP, which again illustrates that the structure of ZIF-65-HYPO is in a less favorable orientation for the uptake of methanol than ZIF-65-HP. In the case of ZIF-90, the hypothetical phase ZIF-90-HYPO also produced less favorable interaction energies with methanol than ZIF-90-HP. However, the interaction energies are much closer (∼1 kJ mol–1 difference) compared to ZIF-65, where the offset between each phase is ∼3 kJ mol–1. These offsets can be clearly shown in methanol–framework interaction histograms in Figures S4–S7.
elements.clean_text: For ZIF-65-HYPO (b), there were no methanol-framework interactions below -30 kJ mol-1, most likely due to the orientation of the framework which is now in a gate-opened structure. With the 4MR window open, this orientation does not allow good contact with methanol. The most favorable sites in ZIF-65-HYPO have energies on the order of -30 to -20 kJ mol-1. These sites, like in ZIF-65-HP, sit in the 6MR window, thereby connecting the pores throughout the crystal lattice, but with less favorable interaction energies (by ca. 5 kJ mol-1) than in ZIF-65-HP. The second site (-20 to -10 kJ mol-1) was also present in the 6MR window and in the central pore, but the mean interaction energy is again around ~5 kJ mol-1 less than that of ZIF-65-HP. The weakest binding site in ZIF-65-HYPO (-10 to 0 kJ mol-1) occupied the center of the pore, and the density was much higher than that in ZIF-65-HP, which again illustrates that the structure of ZIF-65-HYPO is in a less favorable orientation for the uptake of methanol than ZIF-65-HP. In the case of ZIF-90, the hypothetical phase ZIF-90-HYPO also produced less favorable interaction energies with methanol than ZIF-90-HP. However, the interaction energies are much closer (~1 kJ mol-1 difference) compared to ZIF-65, where the offset between each phase is ~3 kJ mol-1. These offsets can be clearly shown in methanol-framework interaction histograms in Figures S4-S7.

elements.content: It is evident that the lowest energy sites (∼-30 to −20 kJ mol–1) dictate the orientation of the linkers in the frameworks. These sites percolate from one pore to another through the 6MR windows and it is therefore clear that increasing the limiting pore diameters of these windows is important for adsorption of methanol through the extended pore network. and illustrate how for ZIF-90-HP and ZIF-65-HP the diameter of the 6MR windows is larger than for their rotated counterpart structures and ZIF-65-HYPO. For ZIF-65, the highly polar −NO2 4MR window can form very strong interactions with methanol, which it could not do if it formed a “gate opened” structure like ZIF-8 or ZIF-90, in addition to creating larger channels for the methanol to percolate through the structure.
elements.clean_text: It is evident that the lowest energy sites (~-30 to -20 kJ mol-1) dictate the orientation of the linkers in the frameworks. These sites percolate from one pore to another through the 6MR windows and it is therefore clear that increasing the limiting pore diameters of these windows is important for adsorption of methanol through the extended pore network.  and  illustrate how for ZIF-90-HP and ZIF-65-HP the diameter of the 6MR windows is larger than for their rotated counterpart structures and ZIF-65-HYPO. For ZIF-65, the highly polar -NO2 4MR window can form very strong interactions with methanol, which it could not do if it formed a "gate opened" structure like ZIF-8 or ZIF-90, in addition to creating larger channels for the methanol to percolate through the structure.

elements.content: In summary, we have demonstrated that the functionality of the imidazole ring dictates the swing effect behavior of SOD ZIFs. By using an alcohol as the hydrostatic medium and by using groups of increasing polarity on the framework in our high-pressure X-ray diffraction experiments, we have demonstrated control over the degree of rotation and thus the critical window diameters. We showed that ZIF-90 undergoes a phase transition to a “gate open” HP phase; however, the degree of rotation of the Im linker is less than that of ZIF-8. In addition, it was demonstrated that ZIF-65 undergoes a transition to a more “gate closed” structure upon application of high pressure. By carrying out of DFT simulations of the framework response to ligand rotation, combined with GCMC simulations in the presence of methanol on the HP structures of ZIF-65, ZIF-90, and ZIF-8, and their hypothetical counterparts where the direction of linker rotation is reversed, the guest–host interactions and framework rotation interactions have been deconvoluted. We have demonstrated the importance of guest–framework interactions in the swing-effect mechanism, which dictate, for SOD topology ZIFs, the direction of the ligand swing. This study opens up the possibilities for exploring these swing-effect frameworks with respect to gas mixtures. Such studies will be invaluable in understanding the competition of guest uptake and how this affects the swing-effect mechanism. By exploiting the control over guest–framework interactions, we can work toward creating bespoke molecular sieves.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have demonstrated that the functionality of the imidazole ring dictates the swing effect behavior of SOD ZIFs. By using an alcohol as the hydrostatic medium and by using groups of increasing polarity on the framework in our high-pressure X-ray diffraction experiments, we have demonstrated control over the degree of rotation and thus the critical window diameters. We showed that ZIF-90 undergoes a phase transition to a "gate open" HP phase; however, the degree of rotation of the Im linker is less than that of ZIF-8. In addition, it was demonstrated that ZIF-65 undergoes a transition to a more "gate closed" structure upon application of high pressure. By carrying out of DFT simulations of the framework response to ligand rotation, combined with GCMC simulations in the presence of methanol on the HP structures of ZIF-65, ZIF-90, and ZIF-8, and their hypothetical counterparts where the direction of linker rotation is reversed, the guest-host interactions and framework rotation interactions have been deconvoluted. We have demonstrated the importance of guest-framework interactions in the swing-effect mechanism, which dictate, for SOD topology ZIFs, the direction of the ligand swing. This study opens up the possibilities for exploring these swing-effect frameworks with respect to gas mixtures. Such studies will be invaluable in understanding the competition of guest uptake and how this affects the swing-effect mechanism. By exploiting the control over guest-framework interactions, we can work toward creating bespoke molecular sieves.

elements.content:
The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/jacs.7b10897.

Crystallographic data (CIF)

All computational and experimental methods; synthesis and methods for high-pressure crystallography, DFT geometry optimization, DFT single-point energy calculations, and grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations; crystallographic data of ZIF-90 and ZIF-65 at pressure; ZIF-65 geometry changes at pressure; density functional theory calculations of linker rotations; grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations of hypothetical ZIF phases (PDF)

(c) Unit cell of ZIF-90 and (d) unit cell of ZIF-65. Zn tetrahedra, cyan; C, black; N, blue; O, red. Note the more closed 4MR of ZIF-65 compared to those of ZIF-8 and ZIF-90. H atoms in all structures and the disorder of the CHO functional group in ZIF-90 have been removed for clarity.

cln_elements.content: (a) ZIF-65-HP, (b) ZIF-65-HYPO, (c) ZIF-90-HP, and (d) ZIF-90-HYPO. All viewed down the 100 direction. Purple shading represents the solvent-accessible volume calculated with a probe size diameter of 3.4 Å (kinetic diameter of methanol) using Mercury. Note in (b) and (d) the smaller channels in the six-membered ring windows.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  (a) ZIF-65-HP, (b) ZIF-65-HYPO, (c) ZIF-90-HP, and (d) ZIF-90-HYPO. All viewed down the 100 direction. Purple shading represents the solvent-accessible volume calculated with a probe size diameter of 3.4 Å (kinetic diameter of methanol) using Mercury. Note in (b) and (d) the smaller channels in the six-membered ring windows.

metadata.title:
Tuning
the Swing Effect by Chemical Functionalization
of Zeolitic Imidazolate Frameworks
